bestBHT.bht: The rebuke and chastisement from Christ are not signs of rejection, but rather demonstrate His abiding and pleading love even towards the lukewarm and careless. Rebuking is part of the Lord's chastening, convicting sin to bring about a change of purpose and ignite zeal in one's life. In His dealings, Christ rebukes those He loves and teaches them righteousness. As a response to His love and correction, Christ urges them to be zealous and repent.

Henry Alford: Rebuke and chastisement are no signs of rejection from Christ, but of His abiding and pleading love, even to the lukewarm and careless.
The rebuking, the convincing of sin, producing conviction, is a portion of the Lord’s chastening.
Change of purpose must, in the fact, precede zeal, which is the effectual working in a man’s life of that change of purpose.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: He scourgeth every son whom He receiveth. And shalt thou be an exception? If excepted from suffering the scourge, thou art excepted from the number of the sons."
I in My dealings, so altogether unlike man's, in the case of all whom I love, rebuke.
In the divine chastening, the sinner at one and the same time winces under the rod and learns righteousness.
Albert Barnes: The meaning is, that it is a proof of love on his part, if his professed friends go astray, to recall them by admonitions and by trials.
Be earnest, strenuous, ardent in your purpose to exercise true repentance, and to turn from the error of your ways.
When the professed followers of Christ have become lukewarm in his service, they should lose no time in returning to him, anti seeking his favor again.
Marvin Vincent: As many as I love. In the Greek order I stands first as emphatic."
Rebuke [ελεγχω]. See on John 3:20. Rev., reprove.
Be zealous [ζηλευε]. The verb is akin to zestov hot in verse 16, on which see note.
Philip Schaff: I, who though I was rich became poor, who bought true riches by suffering and death...
The tenses in the original deserve notice, the first expressing the general habit, the second the decisive act.
Archibald T. Robertson: Be zealous (ζηλευε). Present active imperative of ζηλευω, in good sense (from ζηλοσ, ζεω, to boil), in opposition to their lukewarmness, here only in N.T. (elsewhere ζηλοω), 'keep on being zealous.'
Repent (μετανοησον). Ingressive first aorist active imperative of μετανοεω.

Free rendering of Proverbs 3:12 (in Hebrews 12:6), but with ους εαν (indefinite relative plural) for ον (definite relative singular), with φιλω instead of αγαπα and with the first person παιδευω for παιδευε (the Lord chastens, from παις, child, training a child) and with ελεγχω (reprove) added.
John Gill: The instances of his love to them are many; as his suretyship engagements for them, his assumption of their nature, dying in their room and stead, paying their debts, procuring their peace and pardon, bringing in a righteousness for them, purchasing their persons, his intercession for them, preparations in heaven, supplies of grace, and frequent visits in a kind and familiar manner.

They are rebuked by Christ, not in a way of wrath, but in a tender manner, in order to bring them under a conviction of their sin and of their duty, and of their folly in trusting in, or loving any creature more than himself, and of all their wrong ways.

Zeal was what was wanting in this church; which is nothing else than hot, fervent, and ardent love, love in a flame; whereas she was neither cold nor hot, but lukewarm, Christ would have her be 'zealous' for God.
John Wesley: Whomsoever I love — Even thee, thou poor Laodicean! O how much has his unwearied love to do!
I rebuke - For what is past.
And chasten — That they may amend for the time to come.

bhtAttempts.bht: Rebuke and chastisement are not signs of rejection, but rather a display of Christ's abiding and pleading love, even towards those who are lukewarm and careless. The rebuking and convicting of sin is a part of the Lord's chastening, which aims to bring about a change of purpose and ignite zeal in a person's life. In His dealings, Christ rebukes those He loves so that they may both feel the sting of the rod and learn righteousness. Therefore, he urges them to be zealous and repent, as a response to His love and correction.

Rebuke and chastisement are signs of Christ's abiding and pleading love, even to the lukewarm and careless. The rebuking, the convincing of sin, produces conviction, a portion of the Lord's chastening. Change of purpose precedes zeal, which is the effectual working of that change. In His dealings, unlike man's, Christ rebukes those He loves. In the divine chastening, sinners wince under the rod and learn righteousness. Christ urges them to be zealous and repent in response to His love and correction.

The rebuke and chastisement from Christ are not signs of rejection, but rather demonstrate His abiding and pleading love even towards the lukewarm and careless. Rebuking is part of the Lord's chastening, convicting sin to bring about a change of purpose and ignite zeal in one's life. In His dealings, Christ rebukes those He loves and teaches them righteousness. As a response to His love and correction, Christ urges them to be zealous and repent.

Rebuke and chastisement, even for the lukewarm and careless, are signs of Christ's abiding and pleading love. The Lord uses conviction and rebuking of sin to bring about a change of purpose and kindle zeal in one's life. Christ's dealings are unlike man's; He rebukes those He loves. Divine chastening causes sinners to wince under the rod and learn righteousness. Christ urges them to be zealous and repent, as a response to His love and correction.

Rebuke and chastisement are no signs of rejection from Christ, but of His abiding and pleading love, even to the lukewarm and careless. The rebuking, the convincing of sin, producing conviction, is a portion of the Lord's chastening. Change of purpose must, in the fact, precede zeal, which is the effectual working in a man's life of that change of purpose. He scourgeth every son whom He receiveth. In the divine chastening, the sinner at one and the same time winces under the rod and learns righteousness.
